Chemistry Lab.question: It is unlikely that Mn will hybridize to form bonds and thus will use d orbitals to bond, however Mn is known to be a Lewis acid for many ligands such as porphyrins such as the one shown below. Explain why Mn will like forming 5 bonds here in two sentences or less. Hint: as a Lewis acid, Mn forms covalent bonds when the lone pair on the nitrogen atoms donates two electrons to the Mn-N bond. The same goes for Cl-.
answers: Mn has empty d orbitals that can accept electron pairs from the nitrogen and chlorine ligands. Manganese is d5, which means it can accept 5 electrons to pair up, but does not need to. It is a Lewis acid because the ligands donate electrons to the d orbitals of the central Mn ion

Astronomy.question: The bottom of the curve shown in Image A has a slight upwards curve, which is due to a phenomenon called limb darkening. In your own words, explain what limb darkening is and why it would cause the curved shape we observe in Image A.
answers: The edge of a star is less bright than the center of the star because the star is transparent, and the edge of the star is less hot or dense than the center. This causes the transit light curve to not be flat at the bottom, but rather slightly curved upward.

Astronomy.question: On the graph provided on the answer sheet, sketch the shape the transit light curve would have if limb darkening did not exist. Don’t worry about the impact parameter of the transit, b (i.e., assume b ≈ 0).
answers: A rectangle with a dip in the center

Astronomy.question: The depth of a transit (δ) can help us estimate the size of the planet transiting the star: δ = (Rp/R∗)^2. However, if we use the transit depth from Image A (δ = 0.1% = 0.001), we ﬁnd that the “radius” of Venus is about 22,000 kilometers, which is over 3.6 times the actual value. What is the cause of this discrepancy?
answers: The given radius value was a ratio, and used the solar radius for the host star, not the sun radius.
The radius is of the sun, not the earth.

Astronomy.question: Using the information in Image C, propose a physics-based explanation for your answer to the previous part.
answers: Image C shows a higher surface density for small radii. Higher surface density leads to more frequent collisions which allow for growth of planetesimals.

answers: B; In B, the blade is actively changed to maintain a constant rotational speed. When the wind speed gets too high, the angle of attack of the blade is changed, which causes lift to decrease. Optics.question: The figure below shows the lens of an eye that is focused on a nearby object at point Z. If the eye refocuses on a far object, what happens to the shape of the lens? How?
answers: The lens becomes less convex (flatter). The ciliary muscles relax, which increases the tension in the suspensory ligaments. The ligaments pull on the lens, causing it to become less convex.

answers: This bird has difficulty navigating in the air near the water surface

Ornithology.question: Studies have shown that while rearing its chick, a female of this bird will suddenly double its feeding rate for the chick at a specific point in the breeding cycle. What causes this sudden doubling? (Hint: what happens at this “specific point”?)
answers: Once the chick reaches a certain size, the female will then leave to go forage again, so the remaining parent must make up for the absence and feed twice as much

Ornithology.question: True/False: This bird can sleep while flying day or night.

Observations indicate that the nest is NEVER left unguarded until the young are at least half-grown because other members of this bird’s colony will EAT the eggs/young of an unattended nest. Why would this “eat-your-neighbor’s-young” behavior evolve via natural selection despite the fact that it clearly hurts the bird’s population as a whole?
answers: By eating the young of another, a bird increases the chance of survival for its own young, even if it may hurt other birds of the colony, which is an example of kin selection

Human-provided nest boxes, as shown in the right image, help boost this bird’s populations since wood ducks rely on scarce natural cavities and cannot make their own. King Dedede the Conservationist loves watching these cute birds, so he proposes that we build 12 more nest boxes in close proximity to the one in the right image, forming a “cluster colony” of nest boxes. Is this a good idea? Why or why not?
answers: No. Clustering nest boxes like this often increases interspecies competition and intraspecific brood parasitism, as the Wood Duck does not have cluster colonies in nature, which will lower overall survivorship of the population

Ornithology.question: The genitalia of birds of this family are notoriously intricate (i.e. twisting penises & vaginas). These were taken from an Airboat in a southern Louisiana swamp. It's warm and humid for most of the year and has a mild winter. Do you believe that this individual migrates? Why or why not?
answers: This is not a migratory bird, but a fairly sedentary one. It has such a wide range that it can adapt to most environments. This particular individual is unlikely to leave, since it lives in a warm region with consistent food sources year round. The species is more likely to migrate from areas that will be completely covered in ice in the winter, or dry up with no water in summer.

Ornithology.question: What adaptations does this bird have for sight?
answers: It has a high concentration of cones in its retina for acute daylight vision. It has a large lens and cornea for better light gathering. It also has a tapetum lucidum which increases light availability in low light conditions, improving vision in darkness and/or murky waters.

Ornithology.question: What is Specimen B?

This bird is quite distinctive, so please name the morph pictured both in the Louisiana swamp and in Chicago. Also, name the other two morphs of this animal and why I was unable to catch a picture of one.
answers: Louisiana: Southern Morph. Chicago: Intermediate/Typical Morph. Light morph: very difficult to take pictures because of how rare they are. They also tend to inhabit the westernmost and northernmost portions of the US, with little overlap with the species' intermediate and southern morphs.

Ornithology.question: Describe the nesting habits of this animal and why beaver resurgences in the northern US/Canada aids these habits.
answers: Red-shouldered Hawks typically nest in mature deciduous forests. The rise of beavers creates wetlands and promotes forests around them, allowing greater range and quality habitat for these birds.

Ornithology.question: Name 5 prey items of this bird that are not fish. Next, describe how this bird consumes fish.
answers: Snakes, small mammals, frogs, lizards, insects. Red-shouldered hawks will bring the entire fish up to its perch to dismember and consume.

Ornithology.question: What is Specimen D?

This bird has quite a large range outside of Louisiana at about 30°N latitude. How will this individual's size likely compare to another from Peru at 0°? How about one from Helsinki, Finland at 60°N? What rule can be used to describe this phenomenon, and explain why.
answers: The bird in Peru would be smaller. The one in Finland would be larger. This follows Bergmann's rule: animals in colder climates are larger because they lose less heat due to a lower surface area-to-volume ratio.

Ornithology.question: What is Specimen E?

Out of the swamp and back home just west of Houston, Texas. Now formally in winter, I look out on our backyard oak tree and am surprised! I haven't seen this bird before. These guys really stumped me. What is the etymology of its common and scientific name?
answers: Eastern Bluebird: because of its vibrant blue plumage and location in Eastern North America. Sialia sialis: Sialia is derived from a Greek term for an unknown bird, and sialis comes from the Greek term meaning "to move quickly."

All of the points in the graph are from the same geologic formation. Explain why they all line up on a single line.
answers: Each mineral in a rock/geologic formation has the same exact time passed, but have different initial parent daughter ratios. Those with more initial parents will decay more into the radiogenic daughter compared to those without as much initial parent. This allows it to form a straight line when making the isochron.

This rock is a product of alkaline igneous activity, generally formed in thick continental crustal areas, or in Cordilleran subduction zones. Its formation can be theorized to be from the melt of granitic or igneous protolith to a fairly low degree of partial melting

Match each specimen name with the environment/method in which it forms. 2. This rock is a coarse-grained igneous rock. It usually occurs as large intrusions, dikes, and sills within continental crust. These often form above a convergent plate boundary where an oceanic plate subducts beneath a continental plate.

Match each specimen name with the environment/method in which it forms. 3. This rock is a relatively soft, porous rock that is usually formed by the compaction and cementation of volcanic ash or dust.

Match each specimen name with the environment/method in which it forms. 4. This rock is an intrusive igneous rock that slowly cools deep underground in magma chambers called plutons. This slow cooling process allows easily visible crystals to form. This rock is the product of the melting of continental rocks near subduction zones.

Match each specimen name with the environment/method in which it forms. 5. This rock is a dark-colored, fine-grained, igneous rock composed mainly of plagioclase and pyroxene minerals. It most commonly forms as an extrusive rock, such as a lava flow, but can also form in small intrusive bodies, such as an igneous dike or a thin sill.

Match each specimen name with the environment/method in which it forms. 6. This rock is produced from volcanoes when felsic lava cools and freezes without sufficient time for crystal growth. It is commonly found in areas where the cooling of lava was rapid—such as at the margins of the lava flows and in places where the lava entered a lake or sea.

Anatomy - Digestive.question: Question 44
answers: Consumption of fats delays gastric emptying by increasing secretion of GI hormones such as cholecystokinin and secretion (1 point). Alcohol can be absorbed in the stomach lining directly, but alcohol is more rapidly absorbed in the small intestinal lining given its vastly greater surface area (1 point). Delayed gastric emptying from fat consumption therefore slows down alcohol absorption by keeping the alcohol in the stomach longer (1 point).

Anatomy - Digestive.question: Question 45
answers: Duodenum (1 point), secrete a bicarbonate rich (alkaline) mucus to neutralize stomach acid and to protect the duodenal epithelium (1 point)

(Tiebreaker 4) The graph below shows the number of coral species vs. depth in the Chagos Atoll in the Indian Ocean. Despite the fact that coral species need significant amounts of light to thrive, the maximum number of coral species occurs between a depth of 10 and 20m rather than 1 and 10m. Give one likely reason for this trend.
answers: The shallowest waters in a reef system are often subject to higher wave action, which can limit coral growth. In addition, the shallowest waters can be subject to harmful ultraviolet light. For these reasons, coral species tend to do better at depths somewhat greater than the surface.
